> So you see, we agree.  But I just don't like to dwell on or conclude
> with nebulous generalities (which is where my newly phrased
> statement is heading).  For if we ended on the note that "All in
> all, theoretically, no advantage can be shown to exist over all
> possible problems even when the user provides prior knwoledge
> because the user is no more reliable than any given algorithm," we
> would have achieved theoretical accuracy yet said essentially
> nothing.  This is one reason I sometimes dislike discussions on
> theory since they veer the conversation away from interesting points
> (i.e. the importance of geometrical relations to neural organization
> and computation) onto pleasantly precise yet inconsequential
> generalities.

So I think your newest statement of HyperNEAT's advantages is fine,  
and basically I'm with you until about here. Basically I don't see  
this discussion as having fallen into some kind of black hole of  
vacuousness,rather, I think now that we've gotten a lot of the cruft  
out of the way, we can actually start building a real theory of why  
adding geometry as a parameter might actually be beneficial. We've  
gotten to the key point, and now all we have to do is start to  
explore the class of problems for which using geometry is useful.  
Finding this restricted class would allow us to make wonderful  
statements like, "HyperNEAT with these geometry settings is better  
than NEAT on these domains." Which no longer falls under NFL because  
of the restricted problem set. This might prove fruitful, because, as  
you pointed out earlier in the discussion, one such restricted class  
of domains may just happen to include all the real-world problems  
that we could ever care about.

Of course doing this is going to be difficult, and would probably  
require someone with more math than I have. But the point is it can  
be done, so we can still do empirical research based on the premise  
that this statement is correct.

Anyway, here is how I view the verdict so far:

- We agree completely and we've argued semantics.
- Ken: "Theory often distracts us from interesting problems."
- Joe: "Theory is cool, but hard."

-- 
Joseph Reisinger
http://www.cs.utexas.edu/~joeraii
